normalised: Wildlife conservation is more than just hugging trees; it's vital for a healthy planet and, surprisingly, crucial for our own well-being. India, with its rich biodiversity from the Himalayas to the Western Ghats, has a special responsibility in this arena. Think of the majestic Royal Bengal tiger of the Sundarbans, whose population, thanks to conservation efforts like Project Tiger (launched on first april one thousand nine hundred and seventy three), is slowly recovering.

unnormalised: But why bother? Healthy ecosystems, supported by diverse wildlife, provide us with essential services. Forests regulate water flow preventing floods (remember the devastating floods in Kerala in August 2018?). Pollinators, like bees and butterflies, crucial for agriculture, are facing decline due to habitat loss. Consider the case of migratory birds visiting the Keoladeo National Park in Rajasthan; their presence is an indicator of the overall health of the wetlands.
normalised: But why bother? Healthy ecosystems, supported by diverse wildlife, provide us with essential services. Forests regulate water flow preventing floods (remember the devastating floods in Kerala in August two thousand and eighteen?). Pollinators, like bees and butterflies, crucial for agriculture, are facing decline due to habitat loss. Consider the case of migratory birds visiting the Keoladeo National Park in Rajasthan; their presence is an indicator of the overall health of the wetlands.

unnormalised: Moreover, many rural communities depend directly on wildlife for their livelihoods. For instance, many tribes in Chhattisgarh rely on forest products. Ignoring wildlife conservation is essentially jeopardizing their way of life.

unnormalised: Finally, let's not forget the intrinsic value of wildlife. Future generations deserve to witness the splendor of a snow leopard in Ladakh. Supporting organizations like the Bombay Natural History Society (BNHS), or simply advocating for responsible tourism, can make a difference. We need more folks to be vocal by 15/08/2024, else we might lose this precious part of our heritage.
